articles.headline: A Car a Minute Used to Flow Through Here, but Chaos Now Reigns
articles.snippet: A shipping terminal in Kansas reveals the fundamental problem — no one can plan, and no one is sure what will happen next.
articles.abstract: A shipping terminal in Kansas reveals the fundamental problem — no one can plan, and no one is sure what will happen next.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — Just after 5:30 on a chilly November morning, David Heide arrives at the shipping terminal on the industrial fringes of Kansas City, wondering what fresh torment the day has in store.

articles.headline: With No Resources, Authority or Country, Afghan Ambassador Presses On
articles.snippet: Adela Raz arrived in Washington just before her country fell and has struggled to keep her embassy going. A dinner with U.S. veterans was a priority.
articles.abstract: Adela Raz arrived in Washington just before her country fell and has struggled to keep her embassy going. A dinner with U.S. veterans was a priority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The striped flag still flies in front of the Embassy of Afghanistan here, though the Taliban have used a white one since they reclaimed the country this summer. The embassy staff, loyal to a government that no longer exists, is skeletal and largely unpaid, and it isn’t even clear that the lights will remain on next month.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Sues to Stop Blockbuster Chip Deal Between Nvidia and Arm
articles.snippet: The proposed deal would give Nvidia control over computing technology and designs that rival firms rely on.
articles.abstract: The proposed deal would give Nvidia control over computing technology and designs that rival firms rely on.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday sued to block Nvidia’s $40 billion acquisition of a fellow chip company, Arm, halting what would be the biggest semiconductor industry deal in history, as federal regulators push to rein in corporate consolidation.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Don Clark

articles.headline: How the Politics of Abortion Are Poised to Intensify
articles.snippet: The anti-abortion and abortion rights movements are already beginning to mobilize for a new, deeply unsettled post-Roe political reality.
articles.abstract: The anti-abortion and abortion rights movements are already beginning to mobilize for a new, deeply unsettled post-Roe political reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the Supreme Court now looking likely to weaken or overturn the landmark Roe v. Wade decision on abortion, activists and both political parties are bracing for a new battle over one of the country’s longest-running cultural divides.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Emphasizing Tests, Biden Vows to Fight Omicron With ‘Science and Speed’
articles.snippet: The president’s plan shifts away from a near-singular focus on vaccination, as new cases of the variant have emerged in the United States.
articles.abstract: The president’s plan shifts away from a near-singular focus on vaccination, as new cases of the variant have emerged in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden, confronting a worrisome new coronavirus variant and a potential winter surge, laid out a pandemic strategy on Thursday that includes hundreds of vaccination sites, boosters for all adults, new testing requirements for international travelers and free at-home tests.

articles.headline: A Slow-Motion Climate Disaster: The Spread of Barren Land
articles.snippet: Brazil’s northeast, long a victim of droughts, is now effectively turning into a desert. The cause? Climate change and the landowners who are most affected.
articles.abstract: Brazil’s northeast, long a victim of droughts, is now effectively turning into a desert. The cause? Climate change and the landowners who are most affected.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARNAÚBA DOS DANTAS, Brazil — The land has sustained the Dantas family for more than 150 years, bearing fields of cotton, beanstalks up to a grown man’s hip and, when it rained enough, a river that led to a waterfall.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama

articles.headline: November Jobs Report Shows Weak Hiring but a Surge in the Labor Force
articles.snippet: Employers reported adding 210,000 jobs, the year’s weakest showing, but there were also bright spots. The mixed picture complicated policy prospects.
articles.abstract: Employers reported adding 210,000 jobs, the year’s weakest showing, but there were also bright spots. The mixed picture complicated policy prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employers recorded the year’s weakest hiring in November, adding only 210,000 jobs on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Labor Department said Friday.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Talmon Joseph Smith

articles.headline: What Happened to Amazon’s Bookstore?
articles.snippet: A 2011 thriller was supposed to cost $15. One merchant listed it at $987, with a 17th-century publication date. That’s what happens in a marketplace where third-party sellers run wild.
articles.abstract: A 2011 thriller was supposed to cost $15. One merchant listed it at $987, with a 17th-century publication date. That’s what happens in a marketplace where third-party sellers run wild.
articles.lead_paragraph: John C. Boland was poking around the Amazon bookstore when he saw the science thriller “Hominid” for sale at dizzying prices. It was $907 from Sandy Dunes Surplus, $930 from Rocky Mountain Books and $987 from Open Range Media.

articles.headline: Thefts, Always an Issue for Retailers, Become More Brazen
articles.snippet: In recent months, robberies have been more visible, with several involving large groups rushing into stores and coming out with armloads of goods.
articles.abstract: In recent months, robberies have been more visible, with several involving large groups rushing into stores and coming out with armloads of goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Flash mobs” swarm through a Nordstrom in Northern California and two Best Buy stores in Minnesota, running out with armfuls of merchandise. Five thieves steal $20,000 in products from an Ulta Beauty store in Pennsylvania in just 40 seconds. A security guard is fatally shot in Oakland, Calif., while working with a local television news crew reporting about a recent retail robbery by a group of thieves.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari
